Award.AwardTitle: Boundary Regulation: Output-Recovery Guidance for Nonminimum Phase Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to investigate control methods for cancelling external disturbances for nonminimum-phase systems. Performance of feedback controller is limited for nonminimum-phase systems due to the special structure of the system dynamics. Recent developed non-causal feedforward techniques can only be effective when sufficient preview information of the disturbance is available. This research will investigate feedforward-based control for nonminimum phase systems when the disturbance is not known in advance. The theoretical developments will be for general nonminimum phase systems, and can be applied in diverse applications. The research issues to be addressed are: (i) Stability, since loss of stability can arise with multiple output transitions due to an outer-loop closure; (ii) Performance, e.g. maintaining system output within the desired region under multiple transitions triggered by aggressive disturbances, and (iii) Computation effort. It is important to keep the computational effort at an acceptable level, e.g., approximating the feedforward for output transitions from a set of pre-computed trajectories. Deliverables include tools to design controllers for nonminimum phase systems, conditions for guaranteed stability and performance, documentation of research results, and engineering student education.

This research will impact a variety of applications (with nonminimum phase dynamics), such as, (i) precision control of probe-sample forces to avoid sample damage during high-speed operation of Atomic Force Microscopes; (ii) wind turbines in the presence of wind-gust disturbances that are challenging to measure a-priori; and (iii) flight control of small unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), which are more sensitive to wind disturbances. Graduate and undergraduate engineering students will benefit through classroom instruction and involvement in the research. In addition to dissemination to students and other academics through classes, seminars, publications, and conference presentations, the results will be presented to high-school students and the community through exhibits in annual open houses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research addressed the problem of output-boundary regulation in the presence of disturbances for nonminimum-phase systems, which tend to have performance limitations with feedback. In particular, the proposed work investigates the use of feedforward correction when the disturbance is not known in advance — otherwise (with a-priori knowledge) exact cancellation is possible with feedforward.

 

The main objective was to address the fundamental performance limits for nonminimum-phase systems such as AFM nanopositioners. The limitation arises because of the need to maintain stability. For example, high controller gains can yield better disturbance rejection. However, high gains can lead to overshoot and undershoot problems for nonminimum-phase system. Moreover, high gains can also lead to instability for non-minimum phase systems since the desired output trajectory, which makes them less suited for online implementation when the disturbance is not known a-priori. This motivates the investigation of feedforward addition (to feedback) for improving performance for nonminimum-phase systems when such a-priori (preview) knowledge of the disturbance is not available.

 The addition of feedforward to feedback (since feedforward does not directly influence system stability) can overcome these limitations and achieve perfect compensation of sufficiently smooth disturbances --- even for nonminimum-phase systems, provided, the disturbance is known a-priori. Such (exact-inversion-based) feedforward approaches are non-causal for nonminimum-phase systems, and rely on the use of a-priori (preview) information of the desired output trajectory, which makes them less suited for online implementation when the disturbance is not known a-priori. This motivates the investigation of feedforward addition (to feedback) for improving performance for nonminimum-phase systems when such a-priori (preview) knowledge of the disturbance is not available.

 

We investigated boundary regulation for nonminimum-phase systems where the goal is to maintain the output within a desired region in the presence of disturbances. Output-boundary regulation is important, e.g., in Atomic Force Microscopes (AFMs) when using nonminimum-phase nanopositioners during the imaging soft sample such as cells. Too much output force can damage the soft sample and too less output force can lead to loss of contact. The main contribution of this work was to illustrate how the unstable causal inverse for nonminimum phase systems can be used for rapidly transitioning an output away from the boundary whenever the output approaches the boundary due to a disturbance that is not known in advance. (In contrast, with a-priori knowledge, exact cancellation of the disturbance can be possible using feedforward.) The proposed approach was investigated with simulation results for an AFM imaging example. Simulation results showed that the output-boundary regulation approach can be used to substantially increase the maximum scan frequency, from 8 Hz to 56 Hz, when compared to the case without the boundary-regulation approach.

 

We developed theoretical bounds on the effect of disturbances when using the output-boundary regulation approach Canceling the effects of disturbances is a fundamental control problem that is particularly challenging for nonminimum-phase systems in a variety of technologically-important applications including: (i) maintaining precision control of probe-sample forces to avoid sample damage during high-speed operation of   Atomic Force Microscopes, (ii) wind turbines in the presence of wind-gust disturbances that is  challenging to measure a-priori,  and (iii) flight control of small-unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), which are more sensitive to wind disturbances when compared to larger aircraft, and (iv) non-collocation of input and output which can occur in underactuated mechanical systems. The control challenge arises because typical feedback-based methods have fundamental performance limits for nonminimum-phase systems. Feedforward can alleviate such control challenges – for nonminimum-phase systems, if preview information is available, then exact disturbance cancellation is possible with feedforward. The main contribution if our effort is to develop feedforward control to bound the output error when the disturbance is not known in advance. The application of the proposed approach was illustrated with a benchmark flexible structure example. Simulation results showed substantial performance improvement with the proposed optimal OBR approach (more than 4 times increase in the rate-of-change of the disturbance that can be accommodated) when compared to DC-gain-based or step-input-based approaches.

 

We extended the output-boundary regulation to nonlinear nonminimum phase systems. The main contribution of our work is to show that an output-transition-based OBR (O-OBR, which uses post-actuation input to transition the system state after the output-error transition is completed) can enable OBR of more aggressive output trajectories when compared to a state-transition-based OBR (S-OBR) that transitions the full system state and therefore achieves the output transition as well.

 

The research funded the two undergraduates through the REU program, fully funded the research of one PhD student and partially funded the research of two other graduate students. Ten graduate and undergraduate publications resulted from this work.
